oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Buchanan Dramatic Club is Cultural Influence on Campus"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jones, Frank
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frank Jones, a twenty-five year veteran at the State Teacher's College, wrote this short history of the beginnings of the Buchanan Dramatic Club in 1936. He discusses the nature of the club's first plays and follows the club's evolution over the years of Rebecca Buchanan's tenure.

BUCHANAN DRAMATIC CLUB IS CULTURAL INFLUENCE ON CAMPUS - It was during the year 1925 - 1926 that the Dramatic Club of the State Teachers College was first organized with Miss Rebecca J. Buchanan of the Department of Speech as director. Prior to that, dramatic work, under Miss Buchanan's guidance, had been done in the literary societies, but with the passing of the societies the need was felt for an organization devoted entirely to dramatics. Among the presidents who have served the club are Marion Capps, Elizabeth Stevenson, Katherine Brown, Esther Talley, John Oliver, Ed Bell, Roy Dowdy, Katherine Chambers, Edwin Tarpley, Cecil Webb, and Owen Griffin.The first play produced by the Club was Booth Tarkington's "Seventeen". Among the outstanding productions of the Club, under Miss Buchanan's direction were Oscar Wilde's " Lady Winder-mere's Fan" in which Perry Williamson and Katherine Brown played with notable success. A memorable event in the history of the Club was the staging of R. C. Sheriff's " Journey's End"@( with Ed Bell as Stanhope, Roy Dowdy as Osborne, and Albert Gore in the role of Raleigh. The difficult stage setting was handled with signal success. Another colorful and pleasing production that lingers in the memory of S. T. C. plagoers was " Milestones" by Knoblett and Arnold Bennett in which the work of Katherine Chambers, Florence Betz, and Roy Dowdy was most gratifying. In a lighter vein, but most pleasing, was " The Patsy" featuring Dorothy Gwinn, Katherine Chambers, and John Oliver. In 1932 Miss Buchanan because of illness was obliged to resign the directorship of the Club, and for more than a year the organization continued without any definite leadership, putting on a series of one- act plays. The Club suffered a decline during this period but in 1934 under the leadership of Cecil Webb, Edwin Tarpley, Jane Mankin and others, it was revived and with Mrs. Marion Edney ( the former Miss Dorothy Bachtel of the Science Department), the Club took on new life and began an ambitious series of plays which it has continued since. " Little Women" in which Martha Moore Gracey starred as JO, was a signal success; the spectacular " Hunch Back of Notre Dame" with Cecil Webb in the title role was a feat in staging. Following Mrs. Sadney'J resignation as sponsor of the Club, Mrs. Marshall Burns was chosen sponsor, With " Candida" in 1935 and " Ghosts" in 1936 the Club ventured into the realm of serious drama. Both of these plays were ably directed by Miss Esther Licker who brought to her work a wide knowledge of play production. The effective stage settings by J. B. Peyton, the art director of the Club, have been a notable feature of the productions of the past two years. Time fails to tell of the many who have made the work of the Dramatic Club a success. Its achievements have been due no less to the work of those who have played the leading roles than to those who have sustained the high level of the Club's presentations in the minor roles, to those who have borne the brunt of the technical side of production, and to the rank and file members whose interest and loyal support have kept 2 · ' 3 the Club a live and growing organization. It was in 1934 that it was decided to name the Club for its beloved founder and director for many years, Miss Rebecca J. Buchanan. Though no longer active in directing the work of the organization, she continues to inspire and influcence its endeavors and the Buchanan Dramatic Club in the sincere and effective work which it has done has sought to live up to the high standards which she set for it.
